awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Kevin D. Schreve is "The L^2-Cohomology of Discrete Groups." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientist is Ralf Spatzier.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
There are many deep connections between the geometry of a manifold and its topology, and it is interesting to study how these constrain one other. One of the highlights is the Gauss-Bonnet theorem, which has numerous implications, for instance a sphere or torus cannot admit a metric which is everywhere negatively curved. There are also combinatorial analogues, the most famous being Euler's formula that for any triangulation of the sphere there is the relation # edges + 2 = # vertices + # faces. In the field of geometric group theory, one often tries to understand these connections in a more general algebraic framework. The spaces that one encounters are usually not manifolds, but the idea is the same, how to relate algebraic properties of a group to the geometric/topological properties of a space that the group acts on as symmetries. 

 The main motivation for this project was the Hopf Conjecture, which purports another connection between the geometry and topology of closed nonpositively curved manifolds. Specifically, it predicts that the Euler characteristic (an integer which depends only on the topology) of a (2n)-dimensional manifold has sign (-1)n if it admits a metric of nonpositive curvature. It has been resolved in dimensions 2 and 4 but is open in higher dimensions. A major goal of this project was to study a variant of the Hopf Conjecture inspired by geometric group theory. Adhering to the above philosophy, the right conjecture should be about groups, not just manifolds. It turns out that the "right" variant of Hopf's conjecture states that a certain homological invariant of the group (the L2-Betti numbers) obstructs the group acting properly on Euclidean space of a certain dimension. 

The most significant outcome of this project was a joint paper of the PI with Grigori Avramidi and Boris Okun. In this paper, we showed that a finite field variant of the above conjecture was false. This had many implications, including resolving open questions of Lueck and Bergeron. The paper built on previous work of the PI with Avramidi, Okun, and Mike Davis. The PI also resolved this conjecture in many cases, the most significant was for simple complexes of groups, joint with Mike Davis and Giang Le. 

This project resulted in eight research articles, five of which are currently published and three which are submitted. During the project, the PI spoke twenty times at various seminars and conferences. The travel support helped the PI collaborate with other mathematicians both in the US and abroad.  The project also gave the PI the opportunity to mentor an undergraduate at the University of Michigan REU program, and this project resulted in a research article.
